original_data.question: A 48-year-old man seeks evaluation at a clinic with a complaint of breathlessness for the past couple of weeks. He says that he finds it difficult to walk a few blocks and has to rest. He also complains of a cough for the past 3 months, which is dry and hacking in nature. The medical history is relevant for an idiopathic arrhythmia for which he takes amiodarone daily. He is a non-smoker and does not drink alcohol. He denies any use of illicit drugs. The vital signs are as follows: heart rate 98/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.6°C (99.68°F), and blood pressure 132/70 mm Hg. The physical examination is significant for inspiratory crackles over the lung bases. An echocardiogram shows a normal ejection fraction. A chest radiograph is performed and shown below. Which of the following findings will most likely be noted on spirometry?

options.B: Decreased FEV1 and FVC with decreased FEV1/FVC ratio
options.C: Decreased FEV1 and FVC with normal FEV1/FVC ratio

model_response:
The chest radiograph shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates predominantly in the lower lobes. This patient has a history of recent-onset breathlessness, cough, and crackles on examination. The chest radiograph is consistent with a pulmonary infiltrate. The patient is taking amiodarone, which can cause pulmonary toxicity. The most likely finding on spirometry will be decreased FEV1 and FVC with a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.
Those facilities which administer health services to individuals who do not require hospitalization or institutionalization.
Difficult or labored breathing.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
The result of an examination or inquiry.
An activity in which the body advances at a slow to moderate pace by moving the feet in a coordinated fashion. This includes recreational walking, walking for fitness, and competitive race-walking.
Blockage of the normal flow of the contents of an anatomical passageway.
Freedom from activity.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Removal of moisture from a substance (chemical, food, tissue, etc.).
The act or process of following a person, animal, or object through space or time.

The system of all phenomena in space and time; the totality of physical reality. It is both a scientific and philosophic concept appearing in all historic eras. (Webster 2d; Dr. James H. Cassedy, NLM History of Medicine Division)
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
Occurring or done each day.

A clear, colorless liquid rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and distributed throughout the body. It has bactericidal activity and is used often as a topical disinfectant. It is widely used as a solvent and preservative in pharmaceutical preparations as well as serving as the primary ingredient in ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES.

Drugs that are manufactured, obtained, or sold illegally. They include prescription drugs obtained or sold without prescription and non-prescription drugs. Illicit drugs are widely distributed, tend to be grossly impure and may cause unexpected toxicity.
Actions performed to measure temperature, pulse, respirations, and blood pressure
The number of times the HEART VENTRICLES contract per unit of time, usually per minute.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Crackles that are heard during the inspiratory phase. [PMID:26229557]
The bottom concave portion of the lung that is situated on the convexity of the diaphragm.
Ultrasonic recording of the size, motion, and composition of the heart and surrounding tissues. The standard approach is transthoracic.
Measurement of volume of air inhaled or exhaled by the lung.
